summary: This document set consists of U.S. Marshals Service booking, custody, and medical forms for Jeffrey Epstein following his arrest on July 8, 2019. It includes his personal history, arrest warrant details, custody timeline, medical assessment, and related administrative paperwork. This document is a collection of forms and receipts related to the U.S. Marshals Service filing a Notice of Lis Pendens (Notice of Pendency) against Jeffrey Epstein's property at 9 East 71st Street, New York, owned by Maple Inc. It includes the legal filing, property description, and associated financial vouchers for services like pre-seizure analysis, indicating the government's move to seize the asset as part of the criminal case. This document is a sealed indictment and notice of pendency (lis pendens) filed in the Southern District of New York against Jeffrey Epstein. It charges him with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors from 2002-2005, details the abuse of dozens of minor girls at his New York and Florida residences, and initiates forfeiture proceedings against his New York mansion at 9 East 71st Street. It also includes a US Marshals Service subject report on Epstein. This document is a compilation of US Marshals Service (USMS) reports detailing the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's compliance with International Megan's Law travel reporting requirements, witness interviews regarding sightings of him with young girls, and administrative records related to his custody and death. The investigation was initiated due to suspected unreported international travel and was closed following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the USMS investigation for failure to report international travel as required by International Megan's Law. The reports detail his 2008 conviction, his travel patterns, and his death by suicide in custody on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Barbara Moses
persons.context: Issued the arrest warrant for Jeffrey Epstein on July 2, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary defendant charged with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors. The indictment details his systematic sexual abuse of dozens of minor girls at his residences in New York and Florida from 2002-2005.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed and filed the Notice of Pendency against Epstein's property.

persons.name: Stacy Rider
persons.context: An administrative officer for the U.S. Marshals Service who certified funds and approved a voucher related to the property filing.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Listed as an associate (brother) of Jeffrey Epstein in the US Marshals Service subject report.

persons.name: Senior Inspector (SI)
persons.context: The primary investigator conducting witness interviews, coordinating with the AUSA's office, and submitting search warrants and MLAT requests related to the Epstein investigation. Name is redacted.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Federal prosecutor in the US Virgin Islands with whom the Senior Inspector coordinated to submit Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) requests and a search warrant for Epstein's phone. Name is redacted.

persons.name: Miami Herald reporter
persons.context: Provided information to the Senior Inspector about an airport informant who witnessed Epstein with young girls. Also provided leads on other potential informants, including a disgruntled attorney and a former police chief.

persons.name: Air Traffic Controller
persons.context: An informant who worked at an airport (likely in the US Virgin Islands) and reported to the Miami Herald reporter and later to the Senior Inspector that she observed Epstein disembarking from his plane with young girls appearing to be 11-18 years old between June/July and November 2018.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is prosecuting Epstein and initiating asset forfeiture proceedings against his property.
Epstein directed Employee-1, a New York-based employee, to communicate with victims via phone to arrange sexual encounters at the New York Residence.
Epstein arranged for Employee-2 to contact victims to schedule encounters at his Palm Beach Residence, including calls made from New York to Florida.
Employee-3, an assistant at the Palm Beach Residence, placed phone calls to schedule sexual encounters with minor victims for Epstein.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-1 at the New York Residence over years, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls. He asked her age and she answered truthfully.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-2 at the Palm Beach Residence over years, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-3 at the Palm Beach Residence, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls. He asked her age and she answered truthfully.
Mark Epstein is listed as Jeffrey Epstein's brother in the US Marshals Service subject report.
The Senior Inspector was the lead USMS investigator probing Epstein's compliance with sex offender travel reporting laws.
Collaborated on the investigation, with the AUSA agreeing to submit MLAT requests and review a search warrant for Epstein's phone.
The reporter received information from the air traffic controller about witnessing Epstein with young girls and provided this lead to law enforcement.
Met with the reporter for an interview to gather leads and potential witness information for the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Arrest Warrant Issued
events.description: U.S. Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses issues an arrest warrant for Jeffrey Epstein based on an indictment for sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and taken into federal custody.

events.title: Initial Custody and Booking
events.description: Epstein is processed by the U.S. Marshals Service, photographed, fingerprinted, and medically assessed. He is housed at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Custody Ends
events.description: Epstein's custody status is resolved, with a remark indicating 'SUICIDE' and the case marked as resolved.

events.title: Filing of Notice of Pendency
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a Notice of Lis Pendens against Epstein's property at 9 East 71st Street, initiating forfeiture proceedings related to criminal case 19 CR 490.

events.title: County Clerk Filing and Payment
events.description: The Notice of Pendency is officially filed and recorded with the New York County Clerk's Office, with a $35.00 filing fee paid.

events.title: Beginning of Sex Trafficking Conspiracy
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein begins enticing and recruiting dozens of minor girls to engage in sex acts with him at his New York and Florida residences.

events.title: Abuse of Minor Victim-1 and Scheduling Call
events.description: Epstein sexually abuses Minor Victim-1 at the New York Residence. Employee-1, on behalf of Epstein, places a phone call to Minor Victim-1 to schedule an appointment for paid sex acts.

events.title: Abuse of Minor Victim-2
events.description: Minor Victim-2 is recruited and repeatedly sexually abused by Epstein at the Palm Beach Residence.

events.title: Scheduling Calls for Minor Victims 2 & 3
events.description: Employee-2, located in New York on behalf of Epstein, places phone calls to Minor Victim-2 and Minor Victim-3 in Florida to schedule appointments for paid sex acts. Employee-3 also calls Minor Victim-3 to schedule an appointment.

events.title: Filing of Sealed Indictment and Notice of Pendency
events.description: The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York files a sealed indictment against Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking crimes and a notice of pendency against his New York property.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted under Florida Statute 796.03 for procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution and sentenced to 13 months incarceration.

events.title: Epstein Reports Travel in USVI
events.description: Epstein visited the US Virgin Islands Department of Justice on St. Thomas and signed a Notification of Duty to Report travel, listing a trip to France.

events.title: Unreported Travel to Austria
events.description: Flight tracking data shows Epstein's private jet (N212JE) traveled to Vienna, Austria, a destination not listed on his official travel notification form.

events.title: Epstein Arrested on Federal Charges
events.description: Epstein was arrested by the FBI on federal charges including sex trafficking conspiracy (18 USC 371) and taken into USMS custody.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Investigation Closed
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the USMS Senior Inspector spoke with the USVI AUSA's office and all parties agreed to drop the case, canceling all warrants, MLAT requests, and investigative activities.

events.title: Witness Observations at Airport
events.description: An air traffic controller witness observed Epstein getting off his plane with young girls (ages 11-12 and 16-18) on multiple occasions between June/July and November 2018.

Upper East Side, Manhattan, New York
New York, NY (MCC New York, 500 Pearl St.)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on July 8, 2019, by the FBI on charges of sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors (18 U.S.C. §§ 371, 1591).
The arrest warrant was issued by U.S. Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses on July 2, 2019, in the Southern District of New York (Case No. 19-CR-00490).
Epstein was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York from July 8, 2019, until his death on August 10, 2019, with the custody report noting 'SUICIDE' and 'CASE - RESOLVED'.
Booking documents note special cautions for Epstein including 'Suicidal Tendencies' and 'Mental Concerns'.
The documents include personal identification details, addresses, and official records (passport, driver's license, Medicare card) for Epstein.
The U.S. government filed a Notice of Lis Pendens (Notice of Pendency) against Jeffrey Epstein's property at 9 East 71st Street, NYC, as part of criminal forfeiture proceedings in case 19 CR 490.
The property is legally described as Block 1386, Lot 10 in Manhattan and is owned by Maple Inc., a company linked to Epstein.

The U.S. Marshals Service ordered and paid for a 'Pre-Seizure Package' for the property, including a pre-seizure analysis, desktop broker's price opinion, and preliminary title commitment, totaling $1,092.00.
The filing fee for the Notice of Pendency was $35.00, processed through the New York County Clerk's Office on July 11, 2019.
The document indicates the government's active steps to seize and forfeit Epstein's high-value real estate asset following his indictment.
Jeffrey Epstein is charged with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors from at least 2002 to 2005.
The indictment alleges Epstein sexually exploited dozens of minor girls, some as young as 14, at his mansions in Manhattan and Palm Beach, paying them hundreds of dollars in cash per encounter.
Epstein maintained his supply of victims by paying certain victims to recruit other minor girls, creating a 'vast network' of underage victims.
The U.S. government filed a notice of pendency (lis pendens) seeking forfeiture of Epstein's New York City mansion at 9 East 71st Street, owned by Maple, Inc.
The document references multiple unnamed employees (Employee-1, Employee-2, Employee-3) and unnamed minor victims who facilitated or were subjected to the abuse.

The US Marshals Service was actively investigating Jeffrey Epstein in 2019 for potential violations of International Megan's Law due to his failure to report all international travel as a registered sex offender.
A key witness, an air traffic controller, reported observing Epstein disembark from his private plane with young girls appearing to be between 11 and 18 years old on multiple occasions in 2018.

Flight data obtained by investigators revealed Epstein traveled to countries like Austria and Monaco in March 2019 that were not listed on his official travel notification form submitted to authorities.
The investigation was formally closed on August 12, 2019, two days after Epstein's suicide, with all pending search warrants and international evidence requests (MLATs) being canceled.
Epstein was classified as a Level 3 (highest-risk) sex offender in New York state and was required to register for life, with secondary addresses in Florida, New York, New Mexico, and Paris, France.
